So this shape is called the Rauzy fractal and it was found by GÃ©rard Rauzy. The interest is sort of studying how
matrices act on
three-dimensional space. And there's a lot of nice theory for how, for certain properties of how
matrices act on
two-dimensional space. Especially a matrix, which has one
expansion and one contraction. What that will do is you have these things called
eigenvectors and you pull down in one direction and you expand so that everything gets squashed down and pulled up.
There's a whole theory in that called Markov partitions,
which have - basically have nice properties as you get pulled down and smeared out,
you can turn that into a nice periodic product. And what rauzy asked,
well, what about for the the cubic case when we're dealing with three-dimensional space?
So the specific matrix you're studying here has as one of its

thing you're trying to study, that's how it turns out in these these tiles.
And the golden ratio and Fibonacci numbers are really important in the study of the two-dimensional Markov
partitions, and so when you go up to three dimensions, you have to deal with cubic things. It's quite natural,
it's sort of almost the ancient Greeks who, well, who felt that a cubic number really was a cube.
